description: Benchmark dataset for TRAM retrieval quality testing

memories.text: TypeScript is a statically typed superset of JavaScript that compiles to plain JavaScript. It was developed and maintained by Microsoft.
PostgreSQL is an open-source relational database management system known for its reliability, feature robustness, and performance. It supports JSON, arrays, and custom types.
React hooks were introduced in version 16.8. The most commonly used hooks are useState for state management and useEffect for side effects.
GraphQL is a query language for APIs that allows clients to request exactly the data they need. It was developed by Facebook in 2012 and open-sourced in 2015.
Docker containers are lightweight, standalone executable packages that include everything needed to run a piece of software: code, runtime, system tools, and libraries.
The HTTP status code 404 means 'Not Found', indicating that the server cannot find the requested resource. 500 means 'Internal Server Error'.
JSON Web Tokens (JWT) are an open standard for securely transmitting information between parties as a JSON object. JWTs consist of header, payload, and signature.
Git uses a directed acyclic graph (DAG) to store commits. Each commit points to its parent(s), creating a chain of history that cannot have cycles.
The SOLID principles are: Single Responsibility, Open-Closed, Liskov Substitution, Interface Segregation, and Dependency Inversion. They guide object-oriented design.
SQLite is a serverless, self-contained SQL database engine. It stores the entire database as a single file on disk and is commonly used in mobile apps and browsers.
Redis is an in-memory data structure store used as a database, cache, and message broker. It supports strings, hashes, lists, sets, and sorted sets.
WebSockets provide full-duplex communication channels over a single TCP connection, enabling real-time data transfer between client and server.
The CAP theorem states that a distributed system can only guarantee two of three properties: Consistency, Availability, and Partition tolerance.
OAuth 2.0 is an authorization framework that enables applications to obtain limited access to user accounts. It uses access tokens rather than credentials.
Kubernetes (K8s) is a container orchestration platform that automates deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications across clusters.
To create a new Git branch and switch to it: run 'git checkout -b branch-name' or 'git switch -c branch-name'. The -b/-c flag creates the branch.
To set up a new Node.js project: 1) Run 'npm init -y' to create package.json, 2) Install dependencies with 'npm install', 3) Add scripts to package.json for common tasks.
To debug a Node.js application: 1) Add 'debugger' statements or use --inspect flag, 2) Open chrome://inspect in Chrome, 3) Click 'inspect' on your Node process.
To configure ESLint: 1) Run 'npm init @eslint/config', 2) Answer the prompts for your project type, 3) Add lint script to package.json, 4) Create .eslintignore for exclusions.
To revert a Git commit: use 'git revert <commit-hash>' to create a new commit that undoes changes, or 'git reset --hard <commit-hash>' to remove commits (destructive).
To create a Docker image: 1) Write a Dockerfile with FROM, COPY, RUN instructions, 2) Run 'docker build -t image-name .', 3) Verify with 'docker images'.
To set up TypeScript in a project: 1) Run 'npm install typescript --save-dev', 2) Create tsconfig.json with 'npx tsc --init', 3) Configure compiler options for your target.
To squash Git commits: 1) Run 'git rebase -i HEAD~N' where N is commit count, 2) Change 'pick' to 'squash' for commits to combine, 3) Edit the combined commit message.
To implement pagination in SQL: use LIMIT and OFFSET clauses. Example: 'SELECT * FROM users ORDER BY id LIMIT 10 OFFSET 20' returns page 3 with 10 items per page.
To write a unit test in Vitest: 1) Import describe, it, expect from vitest, 2) Use describe() to group tests, 3) Use it() for individual test cases, 4) Use expect() for assertions.
To handle async errors in Express: wrap route handlers with try/catch, or use a wrapper function that catches errors and passes them to next(). Always have error middleware.
To create database migrations: 1) Generate migration file with timestamp, 2) Write up() for changes and down() for rollback, 3) Run migrations in order, 4) Track applied migrations.
To implement JWT authentication: 1) Create token on login with jsonwebtoken.sign(), 2) Store token client-side, 3) Send in Authorization header, 4) Verify with jwt.verify() middleware.
ground_truth_queries: how to use json web tokens

memories.text: To optimize React renders: 1) Use React.memo() for pure components, 2) Use useMemo() for expensive calculations, 3) Use useCallback() for stable function references, 4) Avoid inline objects in props.
To set up CI/CD with GitHub Actions: 1) Create .github/workflows/main.yml, 2) Define triggers (push, pull_request), 3) Add jobs with steps for install, test, build, deploy.
In yesterday's code review, we decided to refactor the user authentication module to use a more secure password hashing algorithm (argon2 instead of bcrypt).
During the sprint planning on Monday, the team estimated the API redesign would take 2 weeks. We assigned Sarah to lead the effort with Tom as backup.
The production outage last Friday was caused by a database connection pool exhaustion. We fixed it by increasing the pool size from 10 to 50 connections.
In the architecture meeting, we chose PostgreSQL over MongoDB for the new service because we need strong ACID guarantees for financial transactions.
The customer demo on Wednesday went well. They were impressed by the new dashboard but requested a CSV export feature for reports.
We discovered a memory leak in the image processing service during load testing. The cause was unreleased file handles when processing large batches.
The security audit revealed we need to add rate limiting to the login endpoint. They recommended 5 attempts per minute per IP address.
Yesterday's deployment failed because the migration script timed out. We fixed it by breaking the migration into smaller batches of 1000 records each.
The team agreed to switch from Moment.js to date-fns for date handling because Moment is now in maintenance mode and date-fns has smaller bundle size.
During pair programming with Alex, we found that the caching issue was caused by stale ETag headers. We fixed it by adding proper cache invalidation.
The QA team reported 12 bugs from the regression testing cycle. Most were UI alignment issues in the mobile viewport, fixed in commit abc123.
We had to rollback the feature flag changes after users reported slow page loads. Investigation showed the flag evaluation was called too frequently.
In the retrospective, the team identified that unclear requirements caused 3 days of rework. We agreed to have a kick-off meeting before starting any major feature.
The third-party API we depend on went down for 2 hours yesterday. We implemented circuit breaker pattern to handle such failures gracefully in the future.
User feedback from the beta release indicates the onboarding flow is confusing. The main pain point is the account verification email taking too long.
The TRAM project uses a tiered memory system: HOT (actively used), WARM (recently used), COLD (infrequently used), and ARCHIVE (historical, never auto-injected).
Our API follows REST conventions with resource-based URLs. All endpoints are versioned under /api/v1/ and return JSON with snake_case property names.
The project uses Vitest for unit tests and Playwright for E2E tests. Test files are in __tests__ directories next to source files or in a dedicated tests folder.
Database schema uses soft deletes with deleted_at column. The do_not_inject flag serves a similar purpose for memories - keeping them in DB but excluding from auto-injection.
Configuration is loaded from openclaw.json and validated with Zod schemas. Default values are defined in the DEFAULTS constant and merged with user config.
The scoring formula is: score = w_sim * similarity + w_rec * exp(-age/half_life) + w_freq * log(1 + use_count). Each memory type has different half-lives.
CLI commands are implemented in cli/ directory and registered via Commander.js in index.ts. Each command class implements execute() method.
Hooks in TRAM are auto-recall (injects memories before prompts) and auto-capture (extracts memories from responses). They can be enabled per session type.
The decay engine runs on a cron schedule and demotes memories between tiers based on age and usage. Pinned memories are exempt from decay.
Memory types have different decay half-lives: procedural (180 days), factual (90 days), project (45 days), episodic (10 days). These affect the recency component score.
The injection_feedback table tracks usefulness of injected memories. Metrics include access_frequency, injection_density, and proxy_score for self-tuning.
Embedding vectors are stored in a separate table with foreign key to memories. The system uses cosine similarity for vector search with configurable L2 normalization.
Session types (main, cron, spawned) have different default settings for auto-capture and auto-inject. Cron sessions typically have auto-capture disabled to avoid noise.
The TuningEngine auto-adjusts parameters like importanceThreshold based on tier sizes. Users can lock parameters to prevent auto-tuning for a configurable duration.
Error handling follows the Result pattern in core operations. The TramError class extends Error with code and context fields for structured error reporting.
The async/await syntax in JavaScript is syntactic sugar over Promises. An async function always returns a Promise, and await pauses execution until the Promise resolves.
Node.js uses a single-threaded event loop for non-blocking I/O operations. CPU-intensive tasks can block the event loop and should be offloaded to worker threads.
REST API design principles: use nouns not verbs in URLs, HTTP methods indicate actions (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE), and status codes convey results (2xx success, 4xx client error, 5xx server error).
Zod is a TypeScript-first schema validation library. It provides static type inference from schemas using z.infer<typeof Schema> and runtime validation with schema.parse().
The difference between null and undefined in JavaScript: undefined means a variable was declared but not assigned a value, while null is an intentional absence of any object value.
To resolve Git merge conflicts: 1) Open conflicted files and look for <<<<<<< markers, 2) Choose which changes to keep, 3) Remove conflict markers, 4) Stage and commit the resolution.
To profile Node.js application performance: 1) Run with --inspect flag, 2) Open Chrome DevTools, 3) Use Performance tab to record CPU profile, 4) Analyze flame chart for hot functions.
To implement rate limiting: 1) Track request counts per key (IP/user) in Redis, 2) Set TTL matching the window (e.g., 60s), 3) Check count before processing, 4) Return 429 if exceeded.
To add a foreign key constraint in SQLite: use REFERENCES in CREATE TABLE, then enable enforcement with PRAGMA foreign_keys = ON (must be set per connection).
To create an index for query optimization: 1) Identify slow queries with EXPLAIN ANALYZE, 2) Create index on WHERE/JOIN columns, 3) Consider composite indexes for multi-column filters.
The performance review showed our P95 latency increased by 40% after the last release. Root cause was the new logging middleware serializing large request bodies.
We decided to freeze feature development for a hardening sprint after the recent reliability issues. Focus will be on adding monitoring, alerts, and fixing tech debt.
The data migration from the old system completed yesterday. We moved 2.5 million records with 99.97% success rate. The 0.03% failures were due to invalid email formats.
User research interviews revealed that power users want keyboard shortcuts for common actions. We added this to the Q2 roadmap with high priority.
The SSL certificate expired causing a 30-minute outage on the payment service. We set up automated renewal with certbot and added expiry monitoring to prevent recurrence.
The uiHints object in config.ts provides metadata for OpenClaw UI generation. It maps config paths to widget types (slider, number, toggle, select) with their options.
The TierBudgetAllocator distributes injection slots among tiers based on configured weights and maximum tokens. HOT tier typically gets 40%, WARM 40%, COLD 20%.
The ResolvedConfig interface has all fields required (not optional) to ensure type safety. The resolveConfig() function fills in defaults for any missing values.
Memory sources are tracked for debugging: 'user' for manual memory_store, 'auto-capture' for hook captures, 'file:path' for imported files, 'migration' for data imports.
The reporting system supports multiple channels: log (console), telegram, discord, slack. Each channel requires specific environment variables for webhook URLs or bot tokens.
Semantic versioning (SemVer) uses MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH format. MAJOR for breaking changes, MINOR for new features (backward compatible), PATCH for bug fixes.
The Event Loop in JavaScript has phases: timers, pending callbacks, idle/prepare, poll, check, close callbacks. Promise callbacks run in microtask queue between phases.
CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) allows servers to specify which origins can access resources. The Access-Control-Allow-Origin header controls this.
A closure in JavaScript is a function that has access to variables from its outer scope even after the outer function has returned. It 'closes over' those variables.
The spread operator (...) in JavaScript expands iterables into individual elements. It can be used for array copying, merging objects, and passing function arguments.
